title-group.article-title: The Effect of Fire Resistant Hydraulic Fluids on Tapered Roller Bearing Fatigue Life

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright Â© Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc. 1978

abstract.p: Fatigue life testing was performed on tapered roller bearings using several fire resistant hydraulic fluids. The test fluids included an ester-oil blend, synthetic esters, invert emulsions and water glycols. For comparison, tests were also run in a reference petroleum oil and a petroleum type antiwear hydraulic oil of similar viscosities. Test results show that the relative bearing fatigue life compared to the reference oil ranged from 100+ percent for the ester oil blend to 14 to 24 percent for the water glycol.

ref.mixed-citation: H. V. Cordiano, E. P. Cochran and R. J. Wolfe, "Effect of Combustion Resistant Hydraulic Fluids on Ball Bearing Fatigue." Lubrication Engineering, Vol. 12, No. 4, July-August 1956, 261-266.

R. A. Hobbs, "Fatigue Lives of Ball Bearings Lubricated With Oils and Fire Resistant Fluids." Institute of Mechanical Engineers, Elastohydrodynamic Lubrication Symposium, Leeds, England, 1972, Paper No. C1/72.
P. Kenny and E. D. Yardley, "The Use of Unisteel Rolling Fatigue Machines to Compare Lubricating Properties of Fire Resistant Fluids." Wear, 20 (1972), 105-121.

G. C. Knight, "The Assessment of the Suitability of the Hydrostatic Pumps and Motors for Use With Fire Resistant Contact Fatigue Performance Testing of Lubricants, London, England, October 1976.
L. G. Johnson, "The Statistical Treatment of Fatigue Experiments, " Elsevier Publishing Co., 1964.
W. E. Littmann and R. L. Widner, "Propagation of Contact Fatigue From Surface and Subsurface Origins." Journal of Basic Engineering, ASME, September 1966, pg. 64.
